poem:
Choices  
  
He lay in quiet battles,  
confined to dust and air,  
a shell of before,  
  
while love wrapped the room,  
in children's breath,  
whispering past doors.  
  
Untold is the courage  
of wings unseen,  
to leap without echoes—  
the final freedom  
gives voice;  
  
and in that silence,  
he chose the sky  
beyond pain's embrace.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Dying people deserve a choice. Let them make it | Letters Eight years ago, my husband Mark died. Our youngest child had just turned 11. Mark had been ill for five years. Finally, he waited till the kids and I were out of the house, and ended his own life. By the time he died, he was bedridden, in constant discomfort, doubly incontinent, unable to taste, smell, or see much, but when he was well,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
